Posts.Content: I believe we each know what is right for us and what we are willing to put our bodies through.  I am glad you are enjoying life again.  That may be the best medicine of all! Love to you...Roseann
Posts.Title: Latest MRI...

Posts.Content: I will definately friend you on facebook. Roseann
Posts.Title: hello! it's been awhile since i've rambled on :)

Posts.Content: My son just called to tell me that he and his girlfriend just finished a walk in Ohio. He was very proud of himself and so was I. Their team raised $3,400. Roseann
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer walk

Posts.Content: I was 58 and very healthy. Chemo would have only made a 3 percent difference. You are much younger so the decision is different. Such a difficult decision. I chose no chemo but whatever we choose comes with risks? Low and high scores are easier decisions! Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx Score of 19 - What to do? Chemo/No chemo

Posts.Content: That was the same for me over 2 1/2 years ago. They will probably suggest an OncoType DX Test to see if chemo is necessary. I only had radiation based on those test results. I am sure you and your family are relieved. Roseann
Posts.Title: Update-Good news

Posts.Content: What a lovely card and thought! I was home with a bad cold and it really made my day. My husband asked about it and I said, "It's from one of my BC sisters." Roseann
Posts.Title: Chen~You Cheated!!

Posts.Content: Whenever a child dies of any disease, our hearts are broken. We think of all the things this child will never experience. However, your life touches many people and you still have much to do. I think of "It's A Wonderful Life" and all that changed because one person had never lived. My sons have chronic illnesses and it is likely that I will outlive at least one of them. I would trade places with them in a heartbeat. I need to trust that there is an order to life that I do not understand. Hope this makes sense to you. Again, I'm soooo sad at the loss of this wonderful life. Roseann
Posts.Title: Sorry to post such bad news

Posts.Content: I'm sorry if I'm suspicious but are you a cancer survivor? No one has spoken about this before. I have great health insurance and can afford it but I worry about my bc sisters who don't. I hope you are sincere and not trying to cause doubt. We need to have insurance for everyone. It doesn't help to have great insurance for those who can't afford it and have no coverage or limited coverage for those who don't. Roseann
Posts.Title: Senate Health Care Bill Would Allow Insurers to Limit Coverage for Seriously Ill Patients

Posts.Content: There are 3 women who are stage IV in my support group. All are doing well so far. One has been at that stage for seven years. She teaches Yoga and lives a very full life. She recently had some progression which they stopped with a treatment adjustment. Every day we survive gives us the chance for a cure. I know she will do more than hang in there. There is hope. I will keep her in my prayers. Roseann
Posts.Title: Regarding Irishwhispers

Posts.Content: I would benefit by 3% with chemo based on my onco score. Mine was not in my lymph nodes. I decided against chemo after much consideration. I know this is a difficult decision. My only advise is to listen to your "gut". My onc wanted to be sure that if the cancer came back that I wouldn't regret my decision and feel I had not done everything I could. I felt it could come back either way and wasn't willing to risk the damage that chemo could cause to someone who is 58 years old. I may have decided differently had I been 10 years younger. There are risks either way. Roseann
Posts.Title: Finding someone with similar dx

Posts.Content: They just need to find the right course of treatment at this point. I think a new doc can be just what you need. New docs, new information and a new course of treatment that will put your BC in it's place. One of the woman in my support group was told by her onc who is also the head of research at Yale that there are exciting new treatments on the horizon. Some are already available and more are to follow. She was so positive that she gave my friend renewed hope. As difficult as it is, please stay in a place of faith and hope. Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: Update on my reoccurence

Posts.Content: I am 59 and just came from a dinner party hosted by a husband and wife who are both 80. They are vital active, people who don't feel they have lived long enough. If I were triple negative, I would have had chemo just in case. In my case, the oncotypedx test came back with only a 3% improvement in my recurrence score so I opted out of chemo. No one can make this decision for you. It's a tough one but I wouldn't assume that you'll be ready to check out at 80. Roseann
Posts.Title: Just Joined today, May 15,2010 :)

Posts.Content: Hi Paula, I read that walking 30 mins. during treatment will help the treatment work better whether it is chemo or rads (from the book Anti Cancer). However if you are really tired as I was at week 4, listen to your body and get rest. Enough with being a hero, our bodies are telling us what we need in order to get throught this ordeal. It will be over before you know it. Roseann
Posts.Title: Is it normal to be utterly exhausted from rads?

Posts.Content: I mean like our encouaging and loving family. I was trying to explain to my husband why I check in every day. Facing what we have all faced creates a strong bond. Some have said that after treatment I should forget about bc and move on. I have a very full life but forgetting is not going to happen. Who knows what the future holds but one thing is for sure....we'll be here to help each other get through the tough times and celebrate the good times. Hugs to all. Roseann
Posts.Title: Do you want to know something sisters in pink?

Posts.Content: I mean like our encouaging and loving family. I was trying to explain to my husband why I check in every day. Facing what we have all faced creates a strong bond. Some have said that after treatment I should forget about bc and move on. I have a very full life but forgetting is not going to happen. Who knows what the future holds but one thing is for sure....we'll be here to help each other get through the tough times and celebrate the good times. Hugs to all. Roseann
Posts.Title: Do you want to know something sisters in pink?

Posts.Content: I don't like it. I also thought this info was private but they do warn us that it is open to such things. Guess I never thought about it much. Roseann
Posts.Title: Learned something about Facebook that I didn't know

Posts.Content: I own my own agency and know a lot about insurance companies...unfortunately. Life insurance is a challenge after breast cancer for the first 5 years and sometimes longer. However, there are some companies that offer guaranteed amounts. Check on the internet by typing in guaranteed issue life insurance. I just purchased long term care insurance without an issue even though I had stage 1 breast cancer under 2 years ago. I don't sell long term care insurance but the agent told me that bc wasn't a knock out question. I would try another company. Insurance companies...bah humbug! Roseann
Posts.Title: Life Insurance after Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: what other coverage you have and some don't care. We also have to consider the cost and our age has a lot to do with the price. I just turned 60 and if I were buying life insurance at my age, it would be quite expensive so I would look for a policy to cover final expenses rather than a big policy. Every state is different, so if you have a local insurance agency stop in and talk with someone who can give you more advise for your situation. Roseann
Posts.Title: Life Insurance after Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Most states have a noncontestablity clause which states that after you own a policy for 2 years, they cannot deny coverage even for suicide. Contact your State Dept. of Insurance for details on your state's guidelines. Roseann
Posts.Title: Life Insurance after Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Does the worry ever end! All of us face this with every mammo, etc. Shadows, cysts, lumps and bumps can send our fears soaring. Lets take one day at a time. It may be nothing. As my mom always said to me, "You can't solve a problem you don't have yet. Think of the time you will waste if what you are worrying about never happens." That's easier for those who have not faced BC. Consider yourself hugged by me. Please let us know when you get your results. God bless! Roseann
Posts.Title: Definitely NOT Dancing With Ned

Posts.Content: I saw an Oprah last week where she revisited past guests to see what they were up to now. A women who had lost 100 lbs. had gained it all back but is back on the wagon. She and Oprah were discussing a book by Geneen Roth, "Women Food And God". Very interesting. I had the same problem with over eating but it was after all my treatments were done. I now know that I was eating to avoid the emotions and fear I was feeling...my feelings of helplessness. You might find it helpful. Roseann
Posts.Title: Can't stop eating!

Posts.Content: that we are not statistics. There is a terrific book, "The Biology of Belief" which is not a self-help, feel good book. I recommend it to anyone with a life threatening disease because it speaks to the fact that we can make a difference in our prognosis. Another great book is, "Anti-Cancer" which was written by a doctor and brain cancer survivor which tells it like it is about statistics. I attend a support group in CT with the author of "Love, Medicin and Miracles". His name is Dr. Bernie Siegel and he was a surgeon at Yale New Haven Hospital for many years. He was one of the first doctors to address the mind body connection. He has many, many stories about people who were written off as hopeless cases who defied the odds and lived into their 80s or 90s. One woman had every node positive and refused chemo and rads and is still alive today into her 80s. He would not have recommended that and advised her differently but his point is "Who knows!" I think we are better off knowing the stats. Sorry if I sound upset but I think more people die from the fear of their prognosis than the actual disease. Roseann
Posts.Title: Survivors of IBS

Posts.Content: can be a challenge but it sounds like you're doing it. I'm sorry to hear your new diagnosis but as scary as it is it is not without hope. New drugs and new information are being uncovered all the time. The longer we live the better the chances that they will find a cure in our lifetimes. For all of us every day is a gift. Hugs and prayers are coming your way. Roseann
Posts.Title: Next step in my journey

Posts.Content: My "buddy" should have it by Friday. Roseann
Posts.Title: Ornament mailed (sorry it took so long!)

Posts.Content: Diagnosed last Feb/09. This is my 1 yr mark. Roseann
Posts.Title: age when diagnosed?

Posts.Content: Diagnosed last Feb/09. This is my 1 yr mark. Roseann
Posts.Title: age when diagnosed?

Posts.Content: Diagnosed last Feb/09. This is my 1 yr mark. Roseann
Posts.Title: age when diagnosed?

Posts.Content: Sister's have a special bond. Be prepared to feel her spirit with you along your journey. I'm sure she'll never be far away but will be your guardian angel. Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: I Lost My Sister Today

Posts.Content: My birthday is Nov. 4th. Roseann
Posts.Title: When is Your Birthday?

Posts.Content: My birthday is Nov. 4th. Roseann
Posts.Title: When is Your Birthday?

Posts.Content: Sister's have a special bond. Be prepared to feel her spirit with you along your journey. I'm sure she'll never be far away but will be your guardian angel. Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: I Lost My Sister Today

Posts.Content: I sometimes wonder if the scars will ever end. My next one is in June and I'm already dreading it. Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: Update on mammo freak out!

Posts.Content: I was told differently by my surgeon. I decided against the surgery but my insurance would have covered it. With a big difference, it could lead to back issues in the future. I would fight this. Have your doctor write a letter to the insurance carrier explaining why the surgery is necessary in your case. The Susan B. Kolman foundation fought for our right to reconstructive surgery and won. I would contact them as well to confirm your right. They tried to get out of paying for my OncoTypeDX test saying it was out of network. We fought and they paid for most of it. Roseann
Posts.Title: Reduction surgery denied

Posts.Content: You must have been so relieved. We all hate the waiting so I'm glad your news was good. Happy New Year! Roseann
Posts.Title: Biopsy update

Posts.Content: I wouldn't compare your situation to others. The tamoxifen is designed to help keep any cancer cells from growing if your cancer is estrogen receptive. I believe that few who have been "cured" are still on this site because they are off living their lives. There are no guarantees so each of us has to make decisions based on our own judgement with the input of our doctors. I would recommend using every traditioal method available along with every alternative method that makes sense to you. I wish you great health and much happiness. Roseann
Posts.Title: reoccurrences and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: When I first joined a support group (Dr. Bernie Seigel who wrote "Love, Medicine, and Miracles" and many more books has meetings in my area), there were 3 women with Stage IV breast cancer, one with Stage IV lung cancer. The rest of us were in earlier stages of our diseases. I was terrified and wasn't sure I would continue. I'm glad I did. These women are spectacular and so far the women with breast cancer are doing very well. I have learned so much from them. I was raised to believe in the happy ending so when we lost a member to lung cancer after a 1 1/2 year fight, I was shocked. How could this happen? She had 3 young children and a wonderful husband. She had recommended a book to me called, "The Shack" which I read after her death and has helped me accept (but not like) the inevitable. We will lose people we love due to many causes...life does end in death every time. In the meantime, there is lots to enjoy. By the way when my friend was taken due to lung cancer I stayed away from the meetings for 2 weeks. I needed time to grieve in my own way. When I was ready, I went back. I hope you do too. Roseann
Posts.Title: I have to escape for a while

Posts.Content: I wouldn't be basing my decision about chemo on the cost because you can make payment arrangements with the treatment center if necessary. You life is worth whatever it takes. However as others have said, chemo decisions are generally made based on the proven effectiveness chemo has had in destroying cancer cells which may grow and kill us sometime in the future. Depending on the type of cancer we have, different chemos may be used. Chemo has come a long way in recent years although no one wants to put their body throught it. When I was first diagnosed, my husband was againt my having chemo. We had a huge fight about it because I was determined to make my decision based on science not on what people told him about chemo. When all the test results came in, it was decided that chemo would only improve my 10 year reoccurence rate by 3%, so I decided not to have chemo. Please let us know more details about the type and stage of your cancer and someone who is or was in a similar situation will be able to offer more help. PS: Concerning hair loss, the American Cancer Society offers free wigs if you can't afford one. Money wasn't an issue for me so I went online and picked out a great wig. Luckily, I never needed to order it but they have some beautiful and affordable wigs online. There is a women in my support group who had similar concerns and you wouldn't be able to tell she is wearing a wig. She sais it saves her so much time in the morning, she may wear it after her hair grows back. Roseann
Posts.Title: Has anyone out there refused chemo?

Posts.Content: Now that's something to be thankful for! I had similar treatment almost 3 years ago. Roseann
Posts.Title: Good News from the Onc

Posts.Content: You wouldn't be human if you didn't get down over disappointing news. However, your battle is far from over and I know you can live a full life. I have a friend who has been stage IV for 7 years. She is an RN and she teaches yoga! She has had setbacks along the way but they always have found a new protocol that works for quite some time while. Every year she lives is one more year for them to come up with something new. Let yourself feel down for today but please don't let a disappointment take away your hope. If the sadness lasts more than 2 weeks, let your doctors know. Chemo can cause depression and that is also treatable. Most important of all is to love yourself. Do something nice for yourself like getting a peticure or getting your hair done. Life doesn't need to be all about the cancer. Roseann
Posts.Title: If I didn't have kids . . .

Posts.Content: I'm up early and wondering how you are doing. I hope you and your family have a wonderful day. Roseann
Posts.Title: If I didn't have kids . . .

Posts.Content: Other than the cost, it seems like the same product. I have a high deductable plan so we pay $5,000 before anything is covered. We save enough in premium to cover that and can pre-tax what isn't covered. My discounted cost for Arimidex is $340 a month. The generic is $163. Still expensive but a lot less. For me that's a no brainer. Roseann
Posts.Title: Generic Arimidex ????

Posts.Content: Hi Laura, My son is on dialysis and and no one wants that but he is on home dialysis and does it while he is sleeping. He works full time. I will be praying you don't need it but just wanted you to know that it has come a long way and there are options now they never had before. Love and prayers, Roseann
Posts.Title: Hey checking in just got out of hospital need prayers

Posts.Content: Bad things DO happen to good people! I'm so glad you mom is doing well. You will, too. Sounds like your sister will be diagnosed early if she has bc. I was diagnosed when I was being screened as a kidney donor for my son. He almost died and I was the only match. I couldn't imaging that I would ever be happy again. He was on dialysis for 3 1/2 years before I was cleared as a donor. Today is my 6 week post op checkup. We are both doing great. I tell you this because we need to know that there are blessings and not just heart ache ahead. In the turmoil, I was afraid that the bad would never stop happening. Stay hopeful for yourself and your family. I send my love! Roseann
Posts.Title: wanted to vent - sorry

Posts.Content: So this morning at 9am I had my first full mammo after my diagnosis a year ago. I didn't think I was too worried except that I didn't sleep well. When I got there, I was told that the machine was broken and I would need to reschedule. I hate having to have these tests! They hurt and fill me with anxiety. Now I have to wait until Friday. I'm hoping they will read it while I wait otherwise I won't know until the following week. Roseann
Posts.Title: Broken Mammo Machine!

Posts.Content: Today, five years ago, I received my diagnosis of breast cancer.  It was 3 weeks before I was told it was Stage 1 lobular bc.  So glad for every day I have am alive and every birthday is a blessing.  I don't come back to this site as often as I used to but the support I received was wonderful.  Thanks ladies! Roseann
Posts.Title: Five years ago today!

Posts.Content: Hi Wolfi, What you have under your arm is called "breakdown" and is fairly common. You did nothing wrong. Some women get it and some don't. There is a perscription creme they can give you that will help. I know many women who used it. That must be soooo painful. Don't know why you have blisters on the back of your shoulders. The techs told me that when people have radiation for other cancers it can go through to their backs. Maybe it was the angle they used to avoid your organs. I know there is an increased risk of lymphodema during radiation but I don't think it has anything to do with the burns. I don't know for sure but be sure you ask when you call. I'm really sorry you are suffering so much with this treatment. ROseann
Posts.Title: Problems with radiation - need advice

Posts.Content: Hi Wolfi, What you have under your arm is called "breakdown" and is fairly common. You did nothing wrong. Some women get it and some don't. There is a perscription creme they can give you that will help. I know many women who used it. That must be soooo painful. Don't know why you have blisters on the back of your shoulders. The techs told me that when people have radiation for other cancers it can go through to their backs. Maybe it was the angle they used to avoid your organs. I know there is an increased risk of lymphodema during radiation but I don't think it has anything to do with the burns. I don't know for sure but be sure you ask when you call. I'm really sorry you are suffering so much with this treatment. ROseann
Posts.Title: Problems with radiation - need advice

Posts.Content: I'm very sorry for you and your loved ones. My thoughts and prayers are with you. They say time heals all wounds but enough is enough already! Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: Im devastated....need prayers!!!!

Posts.Content: I'm very sorry for you and your loved ones. My thoughts and prayers are with you. They say time heals all wounds but enough is enough already! Hugs. Roseann
Posts.Title: Im devastated....need prayers!!!!

Posts.Content: My right breast is still tender. I was told by my oncologist as well as my surgeon that it was due to the radiation. They both said that it would be tender FOR THE REST OF MY LIFE! So, I guess I better get used to it because I plan to be here for a very long time. Roseann
Posts.Title: Breast still tender 1yr later after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I have been crying off and on all day. I can't get my heart around the loss of Lisa (Moopy). It is always painful to lose a bc sister but this has hit me hard. I really wanted the happy ending for Joe and Moopy. They really deserved it! I am also worried about Joe. I am so sad for him. He offered so much support to so many of us. I will miss him on the boards. So much loss.....so much pain ......so much love. Roseann
Posts.Title: I know I am not alone.
